edu.stanford.nlp.simple

Class Document

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.stanford.nlp.simple.Document

  • public class Document
extends Object
    A representation of a Document. Most blobs of raw text should become documents.
    Author:
    Gabor Angeli

      • setBackend

        public static void setBackend(AnnotatorImplementations backend)
        Set the backend implementations for our CoreNLP pipeline. For example, to a ServerAnnotatorImplementations.
        Parameters:
        backend - The backend to use from now on for annotating documents.

      • useServer

        public static void useServer(String host,
                             int port)
        Use the CoreNLP Server (StanfordCoreNLPServer) for the heavyweight backend annotation job.
        Parameters:
        host - The hostname of the server.
        port - The port the server is running on.

      • useServer

        public static void useServer(String host,
                             int port,
                             String apiKey,
                             String apiSecret,
                             boolean lazy)
        Use the CoreNLP Server (StanfordCoreNLPServer) for the heavyweight backend annotation job, authenticating with the given credentials.
        Parameters:
        host - The hostname of the server.
        port - The port the server is running on.
        apiKey - The api key to use as the username for authentication
        apiSecret - The api secrete to use as the password for authentication
        lazy - Only run the annotations that are required at this time. If this is false, we will also run a bunch of standard annotations, to cut down on expected number of round-trips.

      • useServer

        public static void useServer(String host,
                             String apiKey,
                             String apiSecret,
                             boolean lazy)
        See Also:
        useServer(String, int, String, String, boolean)

      • caseless

        public Document caseless()
        Make this document caseless. That is, from now on, run the caseless models on the document by default rather than the standard CoreNLP models.
        Returns:
        This same document, but with the default properties swapped out.

      • cased

        public Document cased()
        Make this document case sensitive. A document is case sensitive by default; this only has an effect if you have previously called Sentence.caseless().
        Returns:
        This same document, but with the default properties swapped out.

      • serialize

        public CoreNLPProtos.Document serialize()
        Serialize this Document as a Protocol Buffer. This can be deserialized with the constructor Document(edu.stanford.nlp.pipeline.CoreNLPProtos.Document).
        Returns:
        The document as represented by a Protocol Buffer.

      • serialize

        public void serialize(OutputStream out)
               throws IOException
        Write this document to an output stream. Internally, this stores the document as a protocol buffer, and saves that buffer to the output stream. This method does not close the stream after writing.
        Parameters:
        out - The output stream to write to. The stream is not closed after the method returns.
        Throws:
        IOException - Thrown from the underlying write() implementation.
        See Also:
        deserialize(InputStream)

      • deserialize

        public static Document deserialize(InputStream in)
                            throws IOException
        Read a document from an input stream. This does not close the input stream.
        Parameters:
        in - The input stream to deserialize from.
        Returns:
        The next document encoded in the input stream.
        Throws:
        IOException - Thrown by the underlying parse() implementation.
        See Also:
        serialize(java.io.OutputStream)

      • json

        @SafeVarargs
public final String json(java.util.function.Function<Sentence,Object>... functions)

        Write this annotation as a JSON string. Optionally, you can also specify a number of operations to call on the document before dumping it to JSON. This allows the user to ensure that certain annotations have been computed before the document is dumped. For example: 

        
   String json = new Document("Lucy in the sky with diamonds").json(Sentence::parse, Sentence::ner);

        will create a JSON dump of the document, ensuring that at least the parse tree and ner tags are populated.

        Parameters:
        functions - The (possibly empty) list of annotations to populate on the document before dumping it to JSON.
        Returns:
        The JSON String for this document.

      • jsonMinified

        @SafeVarargs
public final String jsonMinified(java.util.function.Function<Sentence,Object>... functions)
        Like the Document@json(Function...) function, but with minified JSON more suitable for sending over the wire.
        Parameters:
        functions - The (possibly empty) list of annotations to populate on the document before dumping it to JSON.
        Returns:
        The JSON String for this document, without unnecessary whitespace.

      • xml

        @SafeVarargs
public final String xml(java.util.function.Function<Sentence,Object>... functions)

        Write this annotation as an XML string. Optionally, you can also specify a number of operations to call on the document before dumping it to XML. This allows the user to ensure that certain annotations have been computed before the document is dumped. For example: 

        
   String xml = new Document("Lucy in the sky with diamonds").xml(Document::parse, Document::ner);

        will create a XML dump of the document, ensuring that at least the parse tree and ner tags are populated.

        Parameters:
        functions - The (possibly empty) list of annotations to populate on the document before dumping it to XML.
        Returns:
        The XML String for this document.

      • xmlMinified

        @SafeVarargs
public final String xmlMinified(java.util.function.Function<Sentence,Object>... functions)
        Like the Document@xml(Function...) function, but with minified XML more suitable for sending over the wire.
        Parameters:
        functions - The (possibly empty) list of annotations to populate on the document before dumping it to XML.
        Returns:
        The XML String for this document, without unecessary whitespace.

      • sentences

        public List<Sentence> sentences(Properties props)
        Get the sentences in this document, as a list.
        Parameters:
        props - The properties to use in the WordsToSentencesAnnotator.
        Returns:
        A list of Sentence objects representing the sentences in the document.

      • coref

        public Map<Integer,CorefChain> coref(Properties props)
        Returns the coref chains in the document. This is a map from coref cluster IDs, to the coref chain with that ID.
        Parameters:
        props - The properties to use in the DeterministicCorefAnnotator.

      • coref

        public Map<Integer,CorefChain> coref()
        See Also:
        coref(java.util.Properties)

      • docid

        Returns the document id of the document, if one was found

      • setDocid

        public Document setDocid(String docid)
        Sets the document id of the document, returning this.

      • asAnnotation

        public Annotation asAnnotation()
        Return this Document as an Annotation object. Note that, importantly, only the fields which have already been called will be populated in the Annotation!

        Therefore, this method is generally NOT recommended.
